itemDescription: British medical doctor, malariologist and soldier

wikipedia_page.main: Brigadier John Alexander Sinton,  (2 December 1884 – 25 March 1956) was a British medical doctor, malariologist, soldier, and a recipient of the Victoria Cross, the highest award for gallantry in the face of the enemy that can be awarded to British and Commonwealth forces.

* Brigadier John Alexander Sinton, Indian Army, WWI
* Brigadier John Alexander Sinton, VC, OBE, FRS, DL - A British military officer, medical doctor and malariologist, who was born on 2 December 1884 and died on 25 March 1956.
* Brigadier John Alexander Sinton VC – 37th Dogras

link_mentions.page: Indian Army during World War I

response: Sinton died at his home, Laurelvale House (later the home of Michael Torrens-Spence), and was buried at Moyallon Friends' Burial Ground, Gilford.  His effects were valued, in 1887, at over £100,000.  Sinton, through his brother John Sinton, was a great-uncle of the soldier and doctor John Alexander Sinton.

Sinton was the eldest son, and heir, of Thomas Sinton of Laurelvale House.  His father founded the family linen firm of Thomas Sinton & Co. Ltd. (flax spinners).  Maynard Sinton attended school at Kendal, Westmoreland and at Newtown School, Waterford.  Sinton's uncle was the linen manufacturer John Sinton owner of the Ravarnette Weaving Company; his cousin, a grandson of the same John Sinton, was the Victoria Cross winner John Alexander Sinton.  He continued to manage the firm following his father's death and took up residence at Ballyards Castle, Armagh.

Pringle stood for the UK Parliament in Fermanagh and Tyrone in the 1922 and 1923 general elections, on each occasion being narrowly defeated by two Nationalist Party members.  In 1924, the Nationalists stood aside, and Pringle was elected alongside fellow Ulster Unionist Party member Charles Falls, easily beating two Sinn Féin members.electionsinireland.org  Pringle did not stand in 1929, when two Nationalist Party members gained the constituency unopposed.  A Presbyterian, Pringle was a cousin of Victoria Cross winning doctor John Alexander Sinton.Christophers, Rickard, "John Alexander Sinton 1884-1956", Biographical Memoirs of Fellows of the Royal Society, vol. 2, 1956

He served as a doctor in the Indian Medical Service from 1914 onwards till Indian independence, when he was heading the Central Malaria Bureau and the Director of the Malaria Institute of India in New Delhi (1936-1947). He was posted on war duty in East African campaign (World War I). After higher education, he was posted in the medical research department and posted in Central Malaria Bureau at Kasauli (later Central Research Institute, Kasauli), where he worked under Rickard Christophers and John Alexander Sinton, both accomplished Malariologists. In 1928, he co-authored a book on conducting surveys for malaria, published by the Indian government under the British Raj. He was the first Assistant Director for the newly created Malaria Survey of India created in 1927 and subsequently became its Director succeeding the founding director, John Alexander Sinton.

response: On 21 May 1857, Sinton married Eleanor Hemington at the Friends' Meeting House at Chatteris, Cambridgeshire. They had six children, among them Walter Lyon Sinton (1858–1933), father of John Alexander Sinton, winner of the Victoria Cross (1916), and Caroline Sinton (1860–1918), grandmother of Lawrence John Hobson, O.B.E., C.M.G. (1922–1991), sometime Political Adviser to the High Commissioner for Aden and the Protectorate of South Arabia.

response: *John Alexander Sinton, Irish soldier and winner of the Victoria Cross (first cousin once-removed of Maynard Sinton)
*John Sinton (1835–1890), Irish-linen manufacturer; younger brother of Thomas Sinton, grandfather of John Alexander Sinton
*Thomas Sinton, Irish linen industrialist (cousin of David Sinton), great-uncle of John Alexander Sinton
